bioghist.p: Alfred J. Johnson (1892-1984) was a researcher on dye chemistry. He received a BS in chemistry at the University of Wisconsin, and before completing his MS, joined the United States Bureau of Chemistry. He served in the army during World War I, and after the war, joined the DuPont Company. He remained at DuPont until his retirement. He was the holder of a number of patents and authored several textbooks.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of two notebooks and a set of loose notes kept by Alfred Johnson. The loose notes were taken by Johnson based on various texts on dye production procedures. One notebook contains a series of abstracts of various chemicals translated from a German encyclopedia of chemical dyes and a list of German, English and American patents for chemical dyes, along with abstracts of how those dyes are derived. The other notebook lists formulas and procedures for obtaining dyes, giving the source of the information. This notebook also includes a few documents related to the DuPont organization. Much of the material is undated, except for the publication dates of the sources Johnson used.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
